'Agricultural engineering' is the engineering discipline that applies
engineering science and technology to agricultural production and processing.
Agricultural engineering combines the disciplines of animal biology, plant
biology, and mechanical, civil, electrical and chemical engineering principles
with a knowledge of agricultural principles. {{cite encyclopedia
|last=Hills |first=David |year=2004 |title=Agricultural engineering
|encyclopedia=The Engineering Handbook |edition=2nd |publisher=CRC Press |isbn=0-8493-1586-
7 |pages=190-1 - 190-9 }}|publisher=McGraw Hill |edition=9 |isbn=0-07-913665-6
}} {{cite book |title=Introduction to Agricultural
Engineering Technology |last=Field |first=Harry |last2=Solie |first2=John
|year=2007 |edition=3rd }}

* design of agricultural machinery, equipment, and agricultural structures
* internal combustion engines as applied to agricultural machinery
* agricultural resource management (including land use and water use)
* water management, conservation, and storage for crop irrigation and livestock
  production
* surveying and land profiling
* climatology and atmospheric science
* soil management and conservation, including erosion and erosion control
* seeding, tillage, harvesting, and processing of crops
* livestock production, including poultry, fish, and dairy animals
* waste management, including animal waste, agricultural residues, and
  fertilizer runoff
* food engineering and the processing of agricultural products
* basic principles of circuit analysis, as applied to electrical motors
* physical and chemical properties of materials used in, or produced by,
  agricultural production
* bioresource engineering, which uses machines on the molecular level to help
  the environment. *Design of experiments related to crop and animal production
